history.content:
If you're particularly worried about doing well in 170, study forward on 170 topics.

Reviewing 70 can be useful, but less directly than one might believe based on other Piazza posts. 70 helps you understand proofs and builds mathematical maturity. Beyond that, the content of 70 is only relevant to understanding a few of the proofs in 170, but not much beyond that. The main thing to get from 70 is the nature and structure of proofs and mathematical maturity. If you know about Expected Values, Variance, and Fermat's Little Theorem, you'll be fine.

Since you added in 61B while I was typing this answer, I will say that a solid understanding of 61B (Graph Theory and Algorithm Formation in particular) will be crucial to success in 170, but the instructors do a pretty good job of introducing topics as if they're new in class. I would still recommend studying for 170 if you want to prepare for the course as all the necessary information is provided in the textbook. It won't hurt, though, to run through the necessary notes in 61B.

Here's a link to the textbook for CS170: http://algorithmics.lsi.upc.edu/docs/Dasgupta-Papadimitriou-Vazirani.pdf

___________________

Imo, 170 concepts weren't very challenging and you really only have to know the bare bones of CS 70 discrete math stuff. It was the ingenuity required to come up with solutions to homework/exam problems that was the really hard part.

If you're particularly worried about doing well in 170, study forward on 170 topics.

The main thing to get from 70 is the nature and structure of proofs and mathematical maturity. If you know about Expected Values, Variance, and Fermat's Little Theorem, you'll be fine.

Since you added in 61B while I was typing this answer, I will say that a solid understanding of 61B (Graph Theory and Algorithm Formation in particular) will be crucial to success in 170, but the instructors do a pretty good job of introducing topics as if they're new in class. I would still recommend studying for 170 if you want to prepare for the course as all the necessary information is provided in the textbook. It won't hurt, though, to run through the necessary notes in 61B.

Here's a link to the textbook for CS170: http://algorithmics.lsi.upc.edu/docs/Dasgupta-Papadimitriou-Vazirani.pdf

children.subject: OP: I'm in the midst of preparing for 170 this summer as well. Let me know if you're serious about preparing, we can review together remotely!

history.content:
Hello, I will be taking 170 this fall after just completing 70. If I feel shaky on some concepts in 70 and did not do as well as I hoped to do, would it better to review 70 concepts or preview 170 concepts during the summer to prepare for 170? 

Thank you

Edit: 70 concepts along with 61B concepts during the summer
history.subject: CS170 after CS70
